   175.01 PAY PERIOD.
   Commencing January 1, 1967, all City employees shall be paid every two
weeks.
(Ord. 66-59. Passed 12-12-66.)
   175.02 TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   All officers and employees of the City not represented by a collective
bargaining agent shall be reimbursed for travel expenses as provided herein.
Travel expenses for officers and employees of the City who are represented by a
collective bargaining agent shall be determined by the prevailing contract
between the City and the collective bargaining agent.
   (a)   Mileage for travel by private motor vehicle shall be reimbursed at the
then currently accepted Internal Revenue rate.
      (Ord. 01-18. Passed 2-26-01.)
   (b)    Reimbursement for travel expenses shall be made only when all of the
following conditions apply:
      (1)    Travel is by privately owned vehicle for which the officer or
employee pays the expense of operating such vehicle.
      (2)    Prior to incurring, such expense travel is authorized by the
department head having supervisory authority over the officer or employee
incurring such expense.
      (3)    Travel is performed only in the regular performance of duties of
the officer or employee on behalf of the City.
      (4)    Travel originates within the City at the regular duty station of
the officer or employee to a destination outside of the City where the officer
or employee conducts business on behalf of the City and the return from such
point to the regular duty station of the officer or employee within the City.
   (c)    Travel expenses incurred for transportation other than privately
owned vehicle shall be reimbursed at the actual cost of such transportation
provided that subsections (b)(2) to (4) hereof, apply.
   (d)    Travel expenses as used in this section shall include those expenses
incurred in attendance at any conference or convention as provided in Ohio R.
C. 733.79.
(Ord. 83-32. Passed Over Veto 8-22-83.)
   (e)    Other expenses are as follows:
      (1)    Meals - Shall be reimbursed at the following rates:
         Up to 9:00 a.m. four dollars ($4.00).
         Up to 1:00 p.m. six dollars ($6.00).
         After 6:00 p.m. ten dollars ($10.00).
         These amounts shall be paid cumulatively.
         (Ord. 94-99. Passed 10-24-94.)
      (2)    Hotel and motel - Actual rate; must present receipted bill.
      (3)    Auto parking - Actual rate; must present receipted bill.
      (4)    Registration fees - For local, State or national meetings.
   175.021 PURCHASE ORDER REQUIREMENTS FOR TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   All travel expense incurred by employees of the City, on behalf of the City,
shall be paid upon presentation of a purchase order and supporting documents,
as prescribed by the City Auditor, which shall clearly itemize the point of
origin and point of destination for all travel expense incurred on behalf of
the City, as per Exhibit "A" which is attached to original Ordinance 81-64.
(Ord. 81-64. Passed Over Veto 9-28-81.)
   175.03 VACATIONS FOR FULL-TIME PERSONNEL.
   (a)    Full-time personnel shall receive an annual paid vacation as
hereinafter provided, or as provided in the prevailing Memorandum of
Understanding between the City and the American Federation of State, County and
Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO, or in the prevailing contract between the City
and the Fraternal Order of Police. Each employee shall become eligible for his
respective vacation on his anniversary date and vacation leave shall be taken
by the employee within the twelve months immediately following the anniversary
date. If an employee fails to take vacation leave as provided herein it shall
be forfeited, as no employee shall receive additional compensation, or pay or
credit for any vacation not taken in accordance with the terms of this section.
(Ord. 83-71. Passed 12-12-83.)
   (b)   In the Divisions of Electricity and Sewers, and Waste Water Treatment
full-time personnel shall be entitled to the following vacations:
      (1)    One week paid vacation after one year's service.
      (2)    Two weeks paid vacation after two years' service.
      (3)    Such vacation shall be set by the superintendent or the director
of the department.
   (c)    In the Division of Streets, full-time personnel shall be entitled to
the following vacations:
      (1)    One week paid vacation after one year's service.
      (2)    Two weeks paid vacation after two years' service.
         (Ord. B-742. Passed 5-14-62.)
   (d)    All City employees who have ten years of service are hereby granted
an annual paid vacation of three weeks.
(Ord. 67-10. Passed 2-13-67.)
   175.04 HOLIDAYS; OVERTIME WORK.
   All hourly-rated and salaried full-time employees of the City except all
part-time employees, including but not restricted to part-time police, fire,
cemetery and meter reader employees, shall be paid an eight hour no-work
holiday for the following holidays which cannot be substituted by other
holidays or by ordinary work days:
New Year's Day
Good Friday
Memorial Day
Independence Day
Labor Day
Thanksgiving Day
Day following Thanksgiving Day
Day before Christmas
Christmas Day
   However, if one of the above designated holidays falls on a Saturday, it
shall be observed on the previous Friday; and if it falls on a Sunday the
Monday following will be observed.
    If a holiday falls on an employee's regular day off, a day will be given to
compensate. Further, if it is necessary for an hourly-rated employee to work on
the above designated holidays he shall be paid the regular pay of standard rate
times the hours worked plus holiday pay.
   If a salaried employee works overtime or on holidays, equivalent pay or time
off shall be given as arranged between the respective department heads and the
Director of Public Safety and/or the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 64-61. Passed 12-28-64; Ord. 72-52. Passed 11-27-72.)
   175.05 HOSPITALIZATION.
   Effective July 1, 1970, the City, through its respective pay funds, hereby
authorizes payment by the Auditor of 100 percent of hospitalization insurance
premiums contracted through a group plan with the City for all full-time
employees, including full-time appointed employees, but not including elected
officials.
(Ord. 70-13. Passed 5-25-70.)
   175.06 SICK LEAVE
   Each full-time employee of the City shall be entitled, for each completed
eighty hours of service, to sick leave of four and six-tenths hours with pay.
Upon approval of the responsible administrative officer of the employing unit
employees may use sick leave for absence due to personal illness, injury,
exposure to contagious disease which could be communicated to other employees
and absence due to illness, injury or death in the employee's immediate family.
Unused sick leave shall be cumulative up to 120 work days.
   The responsible administrative authority of a department shall require an
employee to furnish a satisfactory affidavit or a certificate from a licensed
physician as to the nature of his illness or other acceptable reason for his
absence as provided in this section. No sick leave may be granted to an
employee after his or her retirement or termination of employment.
(Ord. 70-39. Passed 11-9-70.)
   175.07 CONFLICT OF INTERESTS; BOARD OF ETHICS.
   (a)    No member of Council or any elected or appointed official or employee
of the City shall:
      (1)    Act directly or indirectly as attorney, agent, broker or employee
or in any other capacity in behalf of any private person, firm or corporation
interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in any contract,
work or business, or in the sale or acquisition of any property, the cost of
which is payable from City funds; or
(2)    Engage in the practice of law or to represent or to appear in behalf of
an individual or individuals before any court in any matter or controversy in
which the City is a party except on behalf of the City as an officer or
employee, or volunteer opinion evidence against the interests of the City in
any litigation in which the City is a party; or
   (3)    Appear before any board or commission of the City except in the
performance of public obligations or official duties, except that such elected
or appointed officials or City employees may appear before a board or
commission subject to written recommendation of the Board of Ethics and written
approval of Council to such recommendation.
   (b)    No person within a period of one year after termination of his
services as an elected or appointed official or employee of the City shall
appear before any board or commission of the City as counsel, attorney or agent
for or in behalf of any firm, person or corporation, or receive compensation
for any services rendered thereto, in relation to any matter which was under
his charge during the period of his services as such elected or appointed
official or employee.
   (c)    A member of Council or the administration shall publicly disclose on
the official records of Council any direct or financial interest or other
personal or private right he may have in any legislation pending before Council
prior to its third reading and passage, provided that the failure of any member
of Council to make such disclosure does not affect the validity of the
legislation.
   (d)    There is hereby established a Board of Ethics, consisting of three
members who shall be residents of the City, or both political parties and
appointed by the Executive and Annexation Committee of Council, with approval
of Council. Such members shall serve without compensation for three-year terms,
except that of the original appointment one member shall be appointed for a
three-year term, one shall be appointed for a two-year term and one shall be
appointed for a one-year term. The Board shall select its own chairman and set
its own rules.
   It shall be the duty of the Board to render advisory opinions with respect
to subsections (a) through (c) hereof. Such advisory opinions shall be rendered
pursuant to the written request of a member of Council or of any elected or
appointed official or employee of the City.
(Ord. 70-17. Passed 6-22-70.)
   175.08 MERIT REVIEW.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 75-20, passed May 12,
1975.)
   175.09 OVERTIME AUTHORIZATION FORMS.
   (a)    The Mayor, Safety Director and Service Director are hereby authorized
and directed to issue instructions and implement in all City operating
departments orders to adopt and use overtime authorization forms in accordance
with the attached work sheet, marked "Exhibit A" and incorporated herein as
though fully rewritten.
   (b)    No overtime worked by any City employee shall be approved for payment
unless the subject "hours worked in excess of 8 hours per day" form is
authorized by the foreman of the department such employee is working in and is
countersigned by the officer authorizing and approving such overtime, the same
to be sent to the City Auditor for payment during the pay period the overtime
was authorized.
(Ord. 75-10. Passed 3-10-75.)
   175.10 PREVAILING WAGE COORDINATOR.
   (a)    The duties of a prevailing wage coordinator, as defined in Ohio R.C.
Chapter 4115, including all record keeping requirements are hereby assigned to
a regular full-time employee of the City at no extra pay for such employee and
to be maintained as a part of his job description. Such employee shall be
designated by the Mayor.
   (b)    The duties as required by Ohio R.C. Chapter 4115 of the position of
the prevailing wage coordinator shall terminate if and when applicable State
law changes or is repealed which terminates the need for such position within
Ohio municipalities.
   (c)    The service provided to individuals or persons or corporations by the
employee assigned the duties of prevailing wage coordinator, shall be at no
charge for such service.
(Ord. 76-56. Passed 10-11-76.)
   175.11 WAGES FOR SEASONAL, PART-TIME AND TEMPORARY EMPLOYEES.
   (a)    All seasonal, part-time, temporary employees of the City and any
temporary employee holding the office of Secretary to the Mayor for any period
commencing October 16, 1981 and ending January 7, 1983, excluding uniformed
employees in the Police Department and Fire Department as provided by separate
ordinance, shall be paid the Federal minimum wage prevailing at the time of
their employment.
   (b)    All seasonal, part-time, temporary employees of the City and any
temporary employee holding the office of Secretary to the Mayor for any period
commencing October 16, 1981 and ending January 7, 1983, excluding uniformed
employees in the Police Department and Fire Department, shall not be paid under
any classification or wage scales established by the Memorandum of
Understanding between the City and the American Federation of State, County and
Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO.
(Ord. 81-67. Passed 9-28-81; Ord. 87-70. Passed 9-28-87.)
   175.12 TELEPHONE EXPENSE ACCOUNTING PROCEDURES.
   (a)    All long distance telephone charges incurred on behalf of the City
shall be paid only upon purchase order signed by the head of the department
incurring such charges, which purchase order shall have attached thereto a
statement indicating the date, time, number called, person or agency called,
and the reason for the call for each individual long distance telephone call
included in the total charge represented by such purchase order. The statement
of the date, time, number called, person or agency called, and the reason for
the call shall be substantially in the form attached to original Ordinance 83-
17 and incorporated herein as Exhibit "A".
   (b)   The City Auditor is directed to return any purchase order not
complying with the provisions of this section to the department head submitting
such purchase order, and to make no payment thereon until such purchase order
complies with the requirements of this section. Neither the Auditor nor the
Treasurer shall make any payment for telephone charges incurred on behalf of
the City except upon purchase order as provided herein.
(Ord. 83-17. Passed over veto 5-9-83.)
   175.13 BONDS.
   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 733.70, Council establishes the bonds of the following
officers or employees of the City:
Position                              Amount
Mayor                              $15,000
Director of Public Safety and Service 10,000
Superintendent of Utilities           75,000
Water Department Foreman              50,000
Utility Office Clerks                 20,000
Income Tax Secretary/Deputy Treasurer 50,000
Auditor                               50,000
Treasurer                             50,000
Council Clerk                         5,000
(Ord. 98-112. Passed 9-28-98.)
   175.14 INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   If there is no liability or other insurance in place that provides
coverage against claims made against any elected officials, appointed officials
and employees of the City, the City shall hold harmless and indemnify all
elected officials, appointed officials and employees of their conduct while
acting in their official capacity as an official or employee of the City,
provided the official or employee has not acted in a malicious manner and/or
has not acted in a manner beyond the scope of their employment and/or has not
acted in a manner known or that should have been known to them to be improper,
illegal or violative of their duties and/or responsibilities to the City.
   (b)   Nothing in this section shall obligate the City to consult with or
obtain the permission of any official or employee prior to settling or
otherwise resolving any claims made against any official or employee of the
City.
   (c)   Should any claims be made for which the City has responsibility
pursuant to subsection (a) hereof, the City shall also pay and be responsible
for the attorney fees and expenses of suit provided, however, the City shall
have the sole and exclusive right to choose the attorney or attorneys who shall
represent the City and the officials or employees involved.
(Ord. 87-87. Passed 12-14-87.)
   175.15 ELECTED OFFICIALS SALARIES AND BENEFITS.
   The salary for elected officials of the City shall be as provided by Council
from time to time.
   175.16 PICK UP OF PERS SALARY REDUCTION PLAN.
   (a)   The full amount of the statutorily required contributions to the
Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio shall be withheld from the gross pay
of each person within any of the classes established in subsection (b) hereof
and shall be “picked up” (assumed and paid to the Public Employees Retirement
System of Ohio) by the City. This “pick up” by the City is, and shall be
designated as, public employee contributions and shall be in lieu of
contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of subsection (b)
hereof. No person subject to this “pick up” shall have the option of choosing
to receive the statutorily required contribution to the Public Employees
Retirement System of Ohio directly instead of having it “picked up” by the City
or of being excluded from the “pick up”. The City shall, in reporting and
making remittance to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio report that
the public employee’s contribution for each person subject to this “pick up”
has been made as provided by the statute.
   (b)   The “pick up” by the City provided that this section shall apply to
all persons that:
   All employees of the City who are or become contributing members of the
Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio and who are covered under the
agreement between the City and the Ohio Council 8 and Local 277 of the American
Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees AFL-CIO effective January
9, 1991 and expiring May 31, 1992.
 
   (c)   The City’s method of payment of salary to employees who are
participants in PERS is hereby modified as follows, in order to provide for a
salary reduction pick-up of employee contributions to PERS.
   (d)   The total salary for each employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under the City policies. Such total salary of each employee shall be
payable by the City in two parts: (1) deferred salary and (2) cash salary. An
employee’s deferred salary shall be equal to that percentage of that employee’s
total salary which is required from time to time by PERS to be paid as an
employee contribution by that employee, and shall be paid by the City to PERS
on behalf of that employee as a pick-up and in lieu of the PERS employee
contribution otherwise payable by that employee. An employee’s cash salary
shall be equal to that employee’s total salary less the amount of the pick-up
for that employee, and shall be payable, subject to applicable payroll
deductions, to that employee. The City shall compute and remit its employer
contributions to PERS based upon an employee’s total salary. The total combined
expenditures of the City for such employee’s total salaries payable under
applicable City policies and the pick-up provisions of this section shall not
be greater than the amounts it would have paid for those items had this
provision not been in effect.
   (e)   The Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to implement the
provisions of this section to institute the “pick up” of the statutorily
required contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio for
those persons reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable them to obtain
the result in federal and State tax deferments and other benefits.
(Ord. 91-69. Passed 10-28-91.)
   175.17 PICK UP OF POLICE AND FIREMEN’S DISABILITY AND PENSION FUND
CONTRIBUTIONS.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 1994 the full amount of the statutorily required
contributions to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund of Ohio
shall be withheld from the gross pay of each person within any of the classes
established in subsection (b) hereof and shall be “picked up” (assumed and paid
to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund of Ohio) by the City.
This “pick up” by the City is, and shall be designated as, public employee
contributions and shall be in lieu of contributions to the Police and Firemen’s
Disability and Pension Fund of subsection (b) hereof. No person subject to this
“pick up” shall have the option of choosing to receive the statutorily required
contribution to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund of Ohio
directly instead of having it “picked up” by the City or of being excluded from
the “pick up”. The City shall, in reporting and making remittance to the Police
and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund of Ohio report that the public
employee’s contribution for each person subject to this “pick up” has been made
as provided by the statute.
   (b)   The “pick up” by the City provided by this section shall apply to all
persons that:
   All employees of the City who are or become contributing members of the
Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund of Ohio and who are covered
under the agreement between the City and the Ohio Patrolman’s Benevolent
Association effective January 1, 1993 and expiring December 31, 1994.
   (c)   The City’s method of payment of salary to employees who are
participants in PFDPF is hereby modified as follows, in order to provide for a
salary reduction pick-up of employee contributions to PFDPF.
   (d)   The total salary for each employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under the City policies. Such total salary of each employee shall be
payable by the City in two parts: (1) deferred salary and (2) cash salary. An
employee’s deferred salary shall be equal to that percentage of that employee’s
total salary which is required from time to time by PFDPF to be paid as an
employee contribution by that employee, and shall be paid by the City to PFDPF
on behalf of that employee as a pick-up and in lieu of the PFDPF employee
contribution otherwise payable by that employee. An employee’s cash salary
shall be equal to that employee’s total salary less the amount of the pick-up
for the employee, and shall be payable, subject to applicable payroll
deductions, to that employee. The City shall compute and remit its employer
contributions to PFDPF based upon an employee’s total salary. The total
combined expenditures of the City for such employees’ total salaries payable
under applicable City policies and the pick-up provisions of this section shall
not be greater than the amounts it would have paid for those items had this
provision not been in effect.
   (e)   The Auditor is hereby authorized and directed to implement the
provisions of this section to institute the “pick up” of the statutorily
required contributions to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund
of Ohio for those persons reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable
them to obtain the result in federal and State tax deferments and other
benefits.
(Ord. 93-63. Passed 8-23-93.)
   175.18  SEXUAL HARASSMENT.
   (a)   Attached to Ordinance 99-14 and made a part hereof as if fully
rewritten herein is a Sexual Harassment Policy which the same be and hereby is
adopted by the City which shall apply to all employees, elected and appointed
officials and boards of the City.
   (b)   A copy of this policy shall be disseminated to all employees, elected
and appointed officials and boards and the City will provide this policy to all
new employees, elected and appointed officials and boards upon their arrival at
the City for employment.
   (c)   Informational sessions concerning the policy so as to ensure that all
employees understand the City’s commitment to eliminating sexual harassment in
the work place shall be held within ninety days after the adoption of this
Sexual Harassment Policy.
(Ord. 99-14. Passed 1-25-99.)
   175.19  MINIMUM WAGE.
   Notwithstanding any contract or ordinance to the contrary, each employee of
the City shall be paid at a rate not less than that mandated for such employee
by the Constitution of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 07-30. Passed 5-14-07.)
   175.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, in addition to any
other penalty provided, shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both.
(Ord. 70-17. Passed 6-22-70.)
CHAPTER 177
Discrimination
177.01    Fair housing policy.
177.02   Equal employment opportunity; affirmative action program.
177.03   Handicapped policy.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Unlawful discriminatory practices - see Ohio R. 4112.02
   177.01 FAIR HOUSING POLICY.
   (a)    It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the City to which
all elected and appointed officials and employees thereof who exercise
supervisory or discretionary duties that they shall observe to the best of
their understanding and ability Sections 801 through 819 of Title VIII, Fair
Housing of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284 and Ohio R.C.
Chapter 4112 as adopted and amended.
   (b)    The Mayor shall cause to be printed notices of suitable size to be
publicly posted in the Municipal Building evidencing such policy adoption as
the official policy of the City.
   (c)    The Mayor is hereby authorized to present whenever necessary a
certified copy of this section to any public body or agency reasonably
requesting same as evidence of this stated policy.
(Ord. 83-16. Passed 4-11-83.)
   (d)    The Mayor shall appoint a Fair Housing Board to administer the
provisions of this section. The Board shall consist of seven members to be
appointed for concurrent terms of one year. Initial appointments shall be made
seven days after the effective date of this subsection and subsequent
appointments shall be made annually on January 2 each year thereafter.
(Ord. 89-39. Passed 6-12-89.)
   177.02 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY; AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PROGRAM.
   (a)    The various appointing authorities of the City shall take such action
when considering any applicants for employment or appointment to the service of
the City to seek the best qualified individual without regard to race, creed,
religion, sex or national origin.
   (b)    The Mayor is hereby directed to prepare an affirmative action program
for the City which shall include as an essential component thereof an outreach
program which shall make known through media contacts the availability of
hiring opportunities in the service of the City.
   (c)    So far as possible, the Mayor or any appointing authority shall have
within departmental files evidence that employment opportunities, especially at
administrative or executive levels, shall have been made known through
recognized channels of contact with qualified potential minority applicants.
This is not intended to preclude the necessity on certain occasions for
emergency hiring under justifiable conditions.
   (d)    It shall be the intent and purpose that hiring practices shall be
guided by nondiscriminatory hiring procedures and public notice shall at every
reasonable
opportunity be given of such policy.
   (e)    To whatever extent this announced policy deserves further
consideration, the Amherst Civil Service Commission is hereby directed to
review its operating procedures and effect such changes in present procedures
as shall be responsive hereto.
(Res. 83-3. Passed 3-14-83.)
   177.03 HANDICAPPED POLICY.
   (a)    Pursuant to the requirements of Section 51.55 of the Revenue Sharing
Regulations, as published in the Federal Register, on October 17, 1983, the
City advises the public, employees and job applicants that it does not
discriminate on the basis of handicapped status in admission or access to or
treatment or employment in its programs and its activities.
   (b)    The City hereby designates the Director of Public Safety and Service
as the contact to coordinate efforts to comply with this requirement.
   (c)    The Clerk of Council is hereby directed to provide public notice of
the information contained in subsections (a) and (b) hereof, in a manner which
shall insure communication of this information to the visually or hearing
impaired.
(Res. 84-8. Passed 4-23-84.)
CHAPTER 178
ADA Compliance and Oversight Board
178.01   Established.
178.02   Responsibilities.
178.03   Members; meetings.
   178.01  ESTABLISHED.
   There shall be established an ADA Compliance and Oversight Board for the
City of Amherst (hereinafter, the “Board”) comprised of the following
individuals:
   (a)   A Chairman, who shall be appointed by the president of City Council
and who shall be responsible for conducting all meetings of the Board in
accordance with Roberts Rules of Order and in compliance with all relevant
sections of the Amherst Codified Ordinances and the Ohio Revised Code.
   (b)   A Vice Chairman, who shall be appointed by the Mayor and who shall act
in the place of the Chairman in the event of the absence or incapacity of the
Chairman.
   (c)   Three members of the general public who shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of City Council. Each year the Chairman shall
designate one of these members to serve as recording secretary of the Board.
   (d)   The Safety/Service Director, the Director of Law and the Chair of the
Community Development Committee of City Council or their respective
representatives shall serve as ex-officio members of the Board.
      (Ord. 02-20. Passed 3-25-02.)
   178.02 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Board is hereby charged with the following responsibilities. The Board
shall:
   (a)   Conduct and annually review and revise a self-evaluation of the City’s
level of compliance with the Act.
   (b)   Develop and annually review and revise a written ADA Compliance Plan
that identifies areas of non-compliance and makes suggestions for remedial
actions. This plan shall include suggestions in priority order and be submitted
annually to City Council for review, concurrence and adoption.
   (c)   As necessary and appropriate, serve in a consulting and advisory role
to the ADA Coordinator for the City of Amherst.
   (d)   Review all plans for public construction projects initiated by the
City and make any appropriate recommendations for compliance with the ADA
Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG).
   (e)   As requested, consult with private businesses on issues related to
compliance with the Act.
   (f)   Maintain minutes of all meetings of the Board as a public record and
file said minutes with the Office of the Clerk of Council.
      (Ord. 02-20. Passed 3-25-02.)
   178.03  MEMBERS; MEETINGS.
   (a)   The terms of members of the Board shall be as follows: The terms for
the Chairman and Vice Chairman shall be two years. The terms of the other
members shall be three years, except for the initial appointments, which shall
be as follows: one member shall be appointed to a one year term; one member
shall be appointed to a two year term; and one member shall be appointed to a
three year term.
   (b)   Appointments to the Board shall be such that a majority of the
appointed members (i.e., three members) shall be persons covered under the Act
as defined in 28 CFR 35.104 or immediate family members of such persons (e.g.,
father, mother, brother or sister).
   (c)   There shall be no limits placed on the number of terms an individual
may serve on the Board.
   (d)   Members of the Board shall serve without compensation, but may be
reimbursed for any real and actual expenses incurred in the performance of
their duties as members of the Board.
   (e)   All meetings of the Board shall be held in facilities that are readily
accessible to all members of the general public and meet the standards set
forth in the ADAAG.
   (f)   All meetings of the Board shall be open to the public and conducted in
compliance with all legal requirements, including Ohio R.C. 121.22.
(Ord. 02-20. Passed 3-25-02.)
                                                                                                     
CHAPTER 179
Technology Advisory Board
179.01   The Technology Advisory Board.
179.02   Responsibilities.
179.03   Other Board activities and communications.
179.04   Board powers and authority.
179.05   Membership.
179.06   Duties of the officers.
179.07   Special advisor to the Board.
179.08   Meetings.
179.09   Other provisions.
   179.01 THE TECHNOLOGY ADVISORY BOARD.
   The Technology Advisory Board (hereinafter the Board) is created by
ordinance to provide specialized technological advise, on a consultancy basis
to City Council and members of the Administration. It may develop
recommendations at the request of City Council and the members of the
Administration upon which they may take action. At the discretion of the
chairman, the Board may make itself available to provide advice and
consultation to the business community in Amherst with the intent to enhance
the technological welfare of the City. (Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.02  RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   To provide advice and consultation to the administration on
technology-related issues as requested.
   (b)   To review legislation involving the following items: (Items should be
submitted first to the Board for its review and comment during the legislative
processes of City Council.)
      (1)   Plans, tactics or strategies involving Technology;
      (2)   Documentation of minimum skill level (core competencies) for
various personnel position in technology (cable and systems);
      (3)   Expenditures that are outside of the City of Amherst adopted
standards. These areas include:
         A.   Expenditure of funds for any computer software, hardware or
consultants;
         B.   Expenditure of funds for any analog system within any City
department;
         C.   Expenditure of funds for any digital system within any City
department;
      (4)   Cable Television station, consultants, equipment or operation;
      (5)   Contracts, correspondence or requests from the cable television
contractor;
      (6)   Review the annual budget from Cable Television and coordination of
its presentation to Council.
   (c)   Evaluation of customer complaints about Cable TV or other technology
services and formulation of recommendations to address these complaints. (This
function shall be conducted in cooperation with the Safety Service Director.)
   (d)   Maintain minutes of all meetings of the Board and provide copies of
said minutes to the Mayor and the Clerk of Council.
   (e)   Serve as advisory to the Technology Committee of Amherst City Council.
   The recommendations of the Board shall be presented to City Council during
committee discussions of proposed legislation. A representative of the Board
may attend the City Council meeting at which the legislation is being
considered to answer questions. If the Board should determine that the proposed
legislation is incomplete, requires further investigation or is an
inappropriate resolution to the matter presented, the Board has the prerogative
to return such legislation to the originator without approval but with
sufficient comment to enable resolution and reconsideration. Recommendations of
the Board should be in written form.
(Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.03  OTHER BOARD ACTIVITIES AND COMMUNICATIONS.
   (a)   Any citizen or Amherst based business may present agenda items to the
Board for consideration. After review for suitability, the Board may forward
these items, in written form, to the appropriate City department for
consideration.
   (b)   From time to time, City Council or member of the Administration may
ask the Board to conduct research and write special reports. Likewise, the
Board may present reports and recommendations, either orally or in writing, of
its own choosing to City Council. Scheduling of these presentations shall be
through the Clerk of Council.
   (c)   For those actions assigned by City Council or a member of the
Administration, the Board shall have appropriate and necessary access to any
City department/function. Such access shall be at the discretion of and
coordinated through the office of the Safety Service Director.
(Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.04 BOARD POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   (a)   In the performance of its activities and research function, the Board
may request:
      (1)   Access to written reports describing specific functions, processes
or existing technology.
      (2)   The cooperation of the function and its personnel in completing
research required for resolution of issues presented to the Board.
      (3)   Permission to conduct a technology survey and/or inventory for the
function.
   (b)   The Board may also serve as an advisor to the Data Processing
Committee of the City of Amherst.
(Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.05 MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The Board shall consist of the following:
   (b)   A chairman appointed by the president of the City Council who may also
serve as the chairperson of the Technology Committee of City Council.
   (c)   A vice chairperson selected by the Board subject to the advice and
consent of the City Council.
   (d)   No more than seven (7) Amherst residents having no direct financial or
business relationship with the City of Amherst. Specifically, the members shall
not be City employees, City elected officials, current vendors, or vendors who
have bid on any City contract within the past twelve months. The Board members
must possess technological skills and knowledge consistent with the mission of
the Board and experience in one or more Board related functional arenas. These
functional areas include:
      (1)   Computer networking technology;
      (2)   Computer software development;
      (3)   Computer hardware;
      (4)   Other electronic information technology;
      (5)   Internet operations;
      (6)   Cable television systems, technology and management.
   (e)   These members shall be appointed by the President of Council from a
list of prospective members prepared by the chairperson of the Board. The
chairperson of the Board is responsible for insuring that all functional areas
have appropriate representation within the membership.
   (f)   The term of appointment of a Board member shall be two (2) years.
Board members are not limited in the number of two-year appointments that they
may serve.
   (g)   Each year the chairperson shall designate a member of the board to
serve as secretary. (Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.06  DUTIES OF THE OFFICERS.
   (a)   The chairperson shall be responsible for developing the agenda for all
meetings and conducting all meetings. The chairperson shall only vote in the
event of the need to break a tie vote among other members eligible to vote.
   (b)   The vice-chairperson shall serve in the role of the chairperson when
and if the chairperson is unable to attend a called meeting of the board.
   (c)   The secretary shall be responsibility for keeping the minutes of all
board meetings, providing public notice of board meetings which include the
agendas and maintaining any other records of the Board as directed by the
chairperson.
   (d)   As some of the information required for review by the Board may
include sensitive or confidential data, members may be required to sign a non-
disclosure statement developed by the Law Director.
(Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.07 SPECIAL ADVISOR TO THE BOARD.
   (a)   City employees, vendors, citizens, experts, and elected officials may
frequently be asked for input, advice and ideas. They may attend meetings and
the Board may request their attendance at meetings. However, they may not vote
on any formal actions of the Board.
   (b)   The chairperson may invite other non-members of the Board to
participate in discussion when their special knowledge or expertise may add to
the work of the Board. The participation and contributions to any work product
of the Board shall be appropriately noted in the minutes of the Board and any
documents or presentations developed for or on behalf of the Board. (Ord. 02-
31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.08 MEETINGS.
   (a)   All meetings of the Board shall be held in public facilities that are
accessible to all members of the community. Upon request, printed materials and
reports of the Board must be available in alternative format (tape, Braille or
large print) for persons with visual impairments. Given 48 hours notice by a
prospective attendee with a legitimate need, a sign language interpreter must
be available at any/all meetings of the Board.
   (b)   For the purpose of conducting official business, five (5) members of
the Board shall constitute a quorum and all official action requires a majority
vote of the members present. (Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
   179.09  OTHER PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Members of the Technology Advisory Board shall serve on a volunteer
basis with no compensation for their activities as a Board member.
   (b)   No member of the Technology Advisory Board shall be eligible to bid on
any City contract that is related in any way to the actions or discussions of
the Board for a period of one year after he/she ceases to be a member of the
Board.
   (c)   Providing the Board has submitted an annual request for appropriations
and that request has been incorporated into the annual budget of the City of
Amherst, board members may be reimbursed for any real, actual and appropriate
expenses incurred in the performance of their duties as a member of the Board
in accordance with all appropriate City policies and procedures.
   (d)   No action or recommendation of the Board shall be binding on the City
of Amherst, the Administration or City Council. As an advisory entity the Board
is prohibited from going into closed meetings or executive sessions without the
advice, consent and participation of the Law Director and/or their designee.
(Ord. 02-31. Passed 4-8-02.)
                                                                                                      
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial

Mayor's Court
181.01    Authority of Mayor.
181.02    Confinement in lieu of fine.

      Disposition of fines and fees collected by Mayor - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
      Mayor's Court jurisdiction - see Ohio R.C. 1905.01 et seq.

      Preliminary examination; bail - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 2937

   181.01 AUTHORITY OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor, presiding at any trial, may, in the same manner as judges of
county courts, punish contempt, compel the attendance of jurors and witnesses
and establish rules for the examination and trial of all cases brought before
him.
(ORC 1905.28; Ord. B-789. Passed 4-8-63.)
   181.02 CONFINEMENT IN LIEU OF FINE.
   When a fine is the whole or part of a sentence the Mayor's Court may order
the person sentenced to remain confined in the County jail or workhouse or in
the prison of the City until the fine is paid, or secured to be paid, or the
offender is legally discharged, provided that nonpayment is not the result of
the defendant's inability to pay.

CHAPTER 191
Earned Income Tax
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 15-31, Chapter
191 shall be operative until January 1, 2016. See Chapter
192 for Income Tax Effective January 1, 2016.
191.01   Purpose.

paid.

CROSS REFERENCES

      Payroll reductions - see Ohio R.C. 9.42
      Deposit of public moneys - see Ohio R.C. 117.17

      Special funds authorized - see Ohio R.C. 5705.12
