CHAPTER 741
Peddlers, Solicitors and Canvassers
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   License or registration required.
741.03   License application and requirements.
741.04   Registration for charitable or religious canvassing.
741.05   Appeals.
741.06   Carrying and exhibiting license or registration; nontransferability;
written receipt required.
741.07   Business hours restricted.
741.08   Fraud prohibited; revocation of license or registration certificate.
741.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      Littering - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20
      Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
      Trespass - see GEN. OFF.
537.04 
      Fraudulent advertising - see BUS. REG.
701.01
   741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   (a)   “Canvasser” means any person who obtains or seeks to obtain funds for
any charitable or religious cause whatsoever by means of canvassing from place
to place.
   (b)   “Charitable” includes patriotic, philanthropic, social service,
welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, veteran’s medical and
social research, either actual or purported.
   (c)   “Peddler” or “solicitor” means any person who carries with him for the
purpose of sale at retail and immediate or future delivery from place to place
goods, wares, food or merchandise, or any person who in person as principal or
agent, from place to place, sells or otherwise obtains orders or commitments
for the sale, repair or exchange of goods, wares, food or merchandise, or
services.
   (d)   “Religious” or “religion” shall not include the word “charitable” but
shall be given their commonly accepted definitions.
      (Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   (e)   “Wholesale” shall be defined as the sale of goods in large bulk or
quantity that is to be offered for resale by retailers.
(Ord. 05-07. Passed 1-24-05.)
   741.02 LICENSE OR REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   (a)   Subject to divisions (c) and (d) below, no person shall engage in the
business or activity of peddler or solicitor as defined in Section
741.01 in this Municipality without first obtaining a license as provided in
Section
741.03.
   (b)   Subject to divisions (c) and (d) below, all persons acting for or
hired by another as a peddler or solicitor in the Municipality shall obtain a
license as provided in Section
741.03 prior to acting as a peddler or solicitor.
   (c)   No license shall be required of any individual who acts as a peddler
or solicitor on behalf of or for any recognized religious or charitable not for
profit organization. However, subject to division (d) below, no individual
shall act as a solicitor or peddler on behalf of or for such organization
without first having registered with the Chief of Police pursuant to Section
741.04.
   (d)   No license or registration certificate shall be required of any person
for the following:
      (1)   Peddling or soliciting only for the purchase of or subscription for
newspapers to be delivered at the place where the subscription is obtained;
      (2)   Peddling or soliciting only for wholesale delivery to merchants,
manufacturers or other business or manufacturing establishments;
      (3)   Peddling or soliciting on behalf of any religious or charitable
organization;
      (4)   Peddling or soliciting at the invitation or request of the person
contacted; or
      (5)   Peddling or soliciting conducted only among the members of the
entity or organization conducting the peddling or soliciting.
         (Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.03 LICENSE APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Applications for licenses for peddlers or solicitors shall be filed
with the Chief of Police, on a form, along with the license application fee, to
be furnished by the Chief of Police, which shall require, at least, the
following information:
      (1) The name of the applicant;
      (2)   If the applicant is an individual, a physical description of the
applicant;
      (3)   The applicant's social security number or federal identification
number;
      (4)   The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is
employed or for whom he is soliciting, if any, and the length of the
applicant's service with such employer or person;
      (5)   If the applicant is an individual, all places of residence of the
applicant and all employment during the preceding year;
      (6)   The nature and character of the goods to be sold or services to be
furnished by the applicant or the purpose for which funds are being peddled or
solicited; or
      (7)   The names of other municipalities in which the applicant has
recently conducted peddling or solicitation activities.
   (b) Each application shall be granted (and, if granted, the license issued)
or denied within a reasonable time period after the Chief of Police receives
the completed application. Within a reasonable time period means promptly after
the submission of the license application and determined in part by the number
of jurisdictions, contacts, and other sources of information the Chief of
Police, or his designee, must contact to determine whether the applicant meets
the requirements set forth in subsection (c) below. Should an application not
be approved within fifteen business days of its submission, it shall be deemed
denied for purposes of an appeal set forth under Section
741.05.
   (c) If the Chief of Police determines, after an investigation, that the
information furnished under the requirements of division (a) above is correct,
that the applicant proposes to engage in lawful commercial or professional
enterprise, and that neither the applicant nor the enterprise upon which the
applicant proposes to engage constitutes a clear and present danger to the
residents of the Municipality, then the Chief of Police shall issue a license
to the applicant.
   (d) The license application fee charged by the Chief of Police shall be as
set forth from time to time by ordinance. All licenses issued under the
provisions of this chapter shall expire six (6) months after the date the
license is issued.
   (e) A license application fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is hereby
adopted and established for the six-month licenses issued under this chapter.
Said fee is non-refundable and shall be charged for each individual proposed
peddler or solicitor.
(Ord. 12-12. Passed 3-12-12.)
   (f)   In the event that the Chief of Police or his designee determines that
the City would be best served by a background check by means of electronic
fingerprinting or other electronic means to perform a background investigation
on any person seeking a license to engage in the activity of peddler or
solicitor within the meaning of this Chapter
741, the applicant shall, in lieu of submitting a license application fee as
set forth in Section
741.03(e), agree to submit to and bear the expense of such electronic
background check as directed by the Chief of Police or his designee.
(Ord. 16-17. Passed 5-23-16.)
   741.04 REGISTRATION FOR CHARITABLE OR RELIGIOUS CANVASSING.
   A charitable or religious organization on whose behalf persons will engage
in peddling, soliciting, or canvassing within the City shall furnish the
following information to the Chief of Police:
   (a)   The name of the organization;
   (b)   The name, address and the telephone number of the person supervising
the activity;
   (c)   The name of an officer or official of the organization;
   (d)   The nature of the charitable or religious purpose of the organization;
and
   (e)   A list of the name(s) of persons who will be peddling, soliciting or
canvassing.
      (Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.05 APPEALS.
   Any person who has applied for a license or registration certificate in
accordance with this chapter and to whom the Chief of Police has, after a
registration, denied a license or registration certificate may appeal to
Council. Notice of such appeal shall be filed with the Clerk within five (5)
days after the denial by the Chief of Police. Such appeal shall be heard by
Council within thirty (30) days. (Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.06 CARRYING AND EXHIBITING LICENSE OR REGISTRATION; NONTRANSFERABILITY;
WRITTEN RECEIPT REQUIRED.
   (a)   The license or registration certificate issued under the provisions of
this chapter shall be carried at all times by the peddler or solicitor.
   (b)   Licenses or registration certificates issued under the provisions of
this chapter are nontransferable and shall not be used by any person other than
the person identified on the license or registration certificate.
(Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.07 BUSINESS HOURS RESTRICTED.
   No person shall peddle, solicit, canvass or conduct market research, door to
door, at dwelling houses or businesses at random, on sidewalks or streets, at
public places, at private meeting places or in any other manner or place in the
Municipality between 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.
(Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.08 FRAUD PROHIBITED; REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE.
   (a)   No person shall directly or indirectly make or perpetrate any
misstatement, description or fraud in connection with any solicitation or
peddling for any purpose in the City or in any application or report filed
under this chapter.
   (b)   The Chief of Police may revoke at any time any license or registration
certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter for violation of any
provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
   741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which such activities are conducted in violation of
this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 03-85. Passed 7-14-03.)
CHAPTER 751
Taxicabs (Repealed)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Chapter
751  was repealed by Ordinance 09-22, passed May 11, 2009.
CHAPTER 753
Video Service Providers
753.01   Fee.
   753.01 FEE.
   (a)   There is hereby established a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of five percent (5%) to the video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. All video service
providers and cable television operators provided video service in the City
shall apply the VSP Fee Percentage against gross revenues as defined in the
Video Law.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the City on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five days
nor later than sixty days after the end of the each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage as determined above, which
notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such video
service provider that it will begin providing video service in the City
pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 09-12. Passed 3-23-09.)
CHAPTER 755
Alarm Systems
755.01    Compliance with requirements.
755.02   Permit application; approval conditions and fee; existing
installations.
755.03   Connection approval; nonliability of City.
755.04   Installation standards; operation and inspection.
755.05   Disconnection and service termination.
755.06   Excessive false alarms.
755.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Making false alarms - see GEN. OFF.
509.07
         Obstructing official business - see GEN. OFF.
525.07
   755.01 COMPLIANCE WITH REQUIREMENTS.
   No person or business shall install, erect, insert, attach, build, create or
otherwise use any alarm system which by electronic, radio, automatic or
mechanical means on the occurrence of a given event, circumstance or condition
transmits a signal or voice communication for reception by the Amherst Police
Department unless the requirements hereinafter set forth in Section
755.02 have been complied with.
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
   755.02 PERMIT APPLICATION; APPROVAL CONDITIONS AND FEE; EXISTING
INSTALLATIONS.
   (a)    The installation of any alarm system in any building, residence,
warehouse, showroom, factory, commercial building or at any location whatsoever
within the City, causing a signal or voice communication to be transmitted for
reception by the Amherst Police Department alarm panel may be permitted only
upon written application to the Director of Public Safety or his authorized
representative and approval by him or his representative of the application as
indicated by the issuance of a permit per such installation.
   (b)    It shall be a condition of the approval of such application that the
applicant:
      (1)    Install of his own expense, at a location determined by the City
Police Department or Fire Department a telephone line, radio or other such
instrument as may be required to receive the signal or voice communication
message transmitted by the alarm unit. All installation, maintenance, service,
operating and continuing costs of the receiving instrument shall be borne by
the applicant. Proof of the current payment of all charges thereon shall be
presented to the Director of Public Safety by January 30 of each year that such
unit remains in operation.
      (2)    Pay to the City a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) annually for each
protected location concurrently with the approval of application or with the
proof of current payment for issuance or renewal of an installation permit.
   (c)    Any residence or lawful business located within the City may be
equipped with an alarm system for the purpose of detecting and signaling the
presence of a fire or unauthorized intrusion upon compliance with this chapter.
Existing installations shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter
including those pertaining to permits, penalties and fees.
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
   755.03 CONNECTION APPROVAL; NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   (a)    Connection to the Police Department alarm panel as provided for in
Section
755.02 shall be contingent upon the applicant having obtained permission from
the company which maintains the alarm panel system in the Police Station to
make such connection. Permission to connect shall not be denied provided
equipment is compatible, provided charges are paid to such company, and
provided that installation is inspected and approved by the Chief of Police or
his authorized representative.
   (b)    The City will, within its capabilities, endeavor to accommodate every
reasonable application for connection to the Police Department alarm panel as
provided for in subsection (a) hereof. The acceptance of an installation,
issuance of a permit and approval shall not constitute acceptance by the City
of any liability connected with equipment maintenance, answering alarms or for
anything contained herein.
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
   755.04 INSTALLATION STANDARDS; OPERATION AND INSPECTION.
   (a)    All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required
shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters Laboratories and/or the
National Fire Protection Association, and/or any other recognized industry
standard. The applicant may be required to submit evidence of the reliability
and suitability of the equipment to be installed.
   (b)    The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices shall be
adjusted to suppress false indications of fire or intrusions, so that the
devices will not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure change in
water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such as the rattling or
vibrating of doors or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation, or
other forces unrelated to genuine alarms.
   (c)    Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the
City shall furnish such person with instructions as to the way the device
operates, along with maintenance instructions.
   (d)    Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the
City for which a permit is required shall provide for receiving calls for
service directly or through an agent, on a twenty-four hour basis and seven
days a week, and shall respond to such calls within eight hours of the time
they are received.
   (e)    At the time of installation, each alarm equipment supplier shall
furnish to the person for whom an automatic protection device has been
installed, written information as to how service can be obtained at any time,
including the telephone number to call for service. Such person shall be
responsible for having the device repaired as quickly as possible after he
learns, either from his own sources or from notification by the Chief of
Police, that the device is not working properly.
   (f)   The Chief of Police, Fire Chief or any officer designated by them
shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon oral notice, to enter
upon any premises within the City, to inspect the installation and operation of
an automatic protection device or signaling device, the purpose of which is to
report an emergency to the Police Station.
   (g)    All equipment, the use or installation of which is subject to this
chapter, shall be maintained in good operating condition. The Chief of Police
may require that repairs be made whenever he has determined that such are
necessary to assure reliability of operation.
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
   755.05 DISCONNECTION AND SERVICE TERMINATION.
   The receiving unit shall be permitted to remain for only so long as it does
not interfere with the normal daily operation of the Police and Fire
Departments. Upon the determination by the Director of Public Safety that such
alarm system is not an aid to preventing crime or the apprehension of
criminals, fighting fires, or that it is disrupting or interfering with the
daily operation of the Police or Fire Departments, the Director is authorized
to cause the immediate disconnection, termination and removal of such unit.
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
   755.06 EXCESSIVE FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)   When the number of false alarms received by the Police Department or
Fire Department from any one alarm system (either directly via transmission of
an alarm signal by such installation to the Police Department or Fire
Department alarm panel or indirectly as a result of a notification from a
monitoring company) exceeds three (3) during any twelve-month calendar year,
then the owner of the alarm system shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
for each additional false alarm up to and including the sixth (6) false alarm
received during such twelve- month period, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
seventh (7) and eighth (8) alarm during such twelve-month period and one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional false alarm after the eighth
(8th) false alarm received during such twelve-month period.
   (b)   Division (a) of this section shall not apply to false alarms received
during the test period of a system.
   (c)   As used in this section, a “false alarm” shall mean any alarm that is
received by the Police Department or Fire Department that is not the result of
an actual emergency incident for which the alarm was intended.
   (d)   As used in this section, the “test period” for an alarm system shall
mean the period commencing on the date such system is first installed or
substantially modified and ending thirty (30) days thereafter.
(Ord. 05-19. Passed 2-14-05.)
   755.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 78-46. Passed 7-24-78.)
CHAPTER 761
Private Investigators and Security Guards
 
761.01    Definitions.
761.02    Registration required.
761.03   Firearms bearer.
761.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749; OAC Ch. 1301:4-5
   761.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The terms "private investigator", "business of private investigation",
"security guard provider" and "business of security services", as used in this
chapter shall be defined as provided in Ohio R.C. 4749.01 effective November
27, 1985, provided, however, that the terms "private investigator", "business
of private investigation", "security guard provider" and "business of security
services" shall not include a person regularly employed as a full or part-time
officer or patrolman in the City Police Department.
(Ord. 88-16. Passed 3-28-88.)
   761.02 REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No individual, corporation or partnership shall operate as a private
investigator or security guard provider or shall engage in the business of
private investigation or the business of security services within the City
until such individual, corporation or partnership has registered with the
Police Department and upon registration has provided the following:
   (a)    The name, current address and social security number, if an
individual or partnership, of the individual, partnership or corporation
holding the Class A, B or C license issued by the State of Ohio Department of
Commerce pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4749.03 under which such individual, partnership
or corporation is operating, and a copy of such license shall be supplied to
the Police Department upon registration; and
   (b)    The names, current address and social security number of all
employees engaged in the business of private investigation, the business of
security services, or both, are registered with the Police Department and a
copy of the identification card furnished by the State of Ohio Department of
Commerce to such an employee is supplied to the Police Department upon
registration.
      (Ord. 88-16. Passed 3-28-88.)
   761.03 FIREARMS BEARER.
   No person to whom a Class A, B or C license is issued pursuant to Ohio R.C.
4749.03, and no registered employee of such license holder shall carry a
firearm in the course of engaging in the business of private investigation, the
business of security services, or both, unless he receives a notation on his
identification card issued by the State of Ohio Department of Commerce that he
is a firearm bearer, and he is registered with the Police Department, as
provided in Section
761.02, supplying a copy of his identification card indicating such notation.
(Ord. 88-16. Passed 3-28-88.)
   761.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree, and each day such violation is continued shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 88-16. Passed 3-28-88.)

CHAPTER 901
Street Excavations
901.01    Permit required.
901.02   Permit fee.
901.03   Cash security deposit; conditions of issuance.
901.04   Continuing security deposit for numerous openings.
901.05   Return of deposit upon refilling.
901.06   City's remedy in event of noncompliance.
901.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to establish and care for streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01,
723.01
      Openings by City - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
      Change of name, vacating and narrowing streets - see Ohio R.C. 723.04 et
seq.
      Sprinkling - see Ohio R.C. 723.16 et seq.
      Surface treatment - see Ohio R.C. 723.23, 723.31
      Excavation liability - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
      Assessments for street improvements - see Ohio R.C. 701.05, Ch. 727
      Changing established grade - see Ohio R.C. 727.07
      Compulsory service connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06, 743.23
      Vacating of streets and alleys listed - see PRELIM. UNIT,
TABLE C
      Grade levels and street name changes listed - see PRELIM. UNIT,
TABLE G
      Removal of barricades and lanterns - see GEN. OFF.
517.03
      Repair of laterals within road property - see S. & P. S.
911.15 et seq.
   901.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, except an employee of the City while engaged as such, shall make
any excavation in any of the public streets or grounds of the City or create or
maintain any obstruction thereon without first securing a permit from the
Safety-Service Director or Street Department Supervisor.
(Ord. B-366. Passed 9-16-47; Ord. 05-06. Passed 1-24-05.)
   901.02 PERMIT FEE.
   Such permit shall be granted by the Safety-Service Director or Street
Department Supervisor upon filing of a written application therefor and payment
of a eight dollar ($8.00) fee for each permit so issued.
(Ord. B-751. Passed 7-9-62; Ord. 88-69. Passed 12-12-88; Ord. 05-06. Passed 1-
24-05.)
   901.03 CASH SECURITY DEPOSIT; CONDITIONS OF ISSUANCE.
   The Safety-Service Director or Street Department Supervisor shall require
security as a condition of issuance of any such permit which shall be the sum
of five hundred dollars ($500.00) cash. The condition of such permit shall be
that the applicant shall within thirty days of the issuance of such permit
restore such street or public grounds to its former condition. In the event of
the failure of such applicant to do so, the City may restore such public
grounds or street at the expense of the applicant. The Safety-Service Director
or Street Department Supervisor shall further require as a condition precedent
to the issuance of any such permit that the applicant will save and hold the
City harmless from any damages suffered by any person resulting from such
excavation or obstruction. In addition thereto as a condition to the issuance
of such permit, the Safety-Service Director or Street Department Supervisor
shall require the erection and maintenance of such proper and reasonable
barricade or other safeguards as he may deem necessary for the protection of
the public until the opening is closed and resurfaced.
(Ord. 78-54. Passed 9-25-78; Ord. 05-06. Passed 1-24-05.)
   901.04 CONTINUING SECURITY DEPOSIT FOR NUMEROUS OPENINGS.
   Whoever because of the nature of the work involved finds it necessary to
make a number of openings in the public streets may in lieu of the one thousand
dollars ($1,000) cash deposit, deposit with the Safety-Service Director or
Street Department Supervisor the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000) cash
which amount shall be accepted without in any way otherwise relieving the
permittee from any of the obligations of this chapter. Such deposit shall be in
full force and effect until withdrawn by the permittee. However, if in the
judgment of the Safety-Service Director or Street Department Supervisor, the
permittee furnishing such deposit fails to provide for and to do the necessary
refilling and resurfacing of openings, he may require that such permittee
follow the procedure of Section
901.03 requiring individual deposits for each and every opening.
(Ord. 78-54. Passed 9-25-78; Ord. 05-06. Passed 1-24-05.)
   901.05 RETURN OF DEPOSIT UPON REFILLING.
   (a)    The required deposit shall be returned to the permittee, provided
that such opening is refilled under the following specifications:
      (1)    #304 limestone for all backfill.
      (2)    All asphalt or bituminous streets shall be backfilled with #304
limestone, eight inches of Class "C" concrete, two inches of #404 asphalt
concrete. All openings, before the final two inches of asphalt concrete is
placed, must have straight edges, and the area must have tack coat SS-1 or
equivalent. All joints must be sealed with AC-20 or equivalent.
      (3)    All concrete streets shall be backfilled with #304 limestone, a
minimum of eight inches Class "C" concrete and all joints shall be sealed.
   (b)    The return of the deposit shall be made upon the refilling being
acceptable to the Street Foreman in material and workmanship.
(Ord. 76-15. Passed 3-22-76.)
   901.06 CITY'S REMEDY IN EVENT OF NONCOMPLIANCE.
   Upon the failure of the permittee to properly close the opening within the
period of thirty days, the City shall cause the opening to be properly closed
and such expense shall be charged to the permittee. The deposit shall be
retained by the City to cover the expenses incurred in closing and restoration
to the former condition.
(Ord. B-751. Passed 7-9-62.)
   901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Any such violations shall
constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued.
(Ord. 05-06. Passed 1-24-05.)
CHAPTER 903
Sidewalks
903.01    Authority.

CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
      Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
      Assessment of costs of improvements - see Ohio R.C. 729.04 et seq.
      Duty to keep sidewalks in repair and clean - see GEN. OFF.

      Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.

      Sidewalks to be clear of ice and snow - see GEN. OFF.

      Streets and Sidewalks Repair Advisory Committee - see ADM.

   903.01 AUTHORITY.
   For the construction or repair of sidewalks within the City right-of-way the
procedures and assessments shall be in accordance with Ohio R.C. 729.01 through
729.10, and Ohio R.C. 735.02, 735.05 and 735.32 and other applicable State
statutes and/or resolutions or ordinances of the City pertinent to the subject
matter herein.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.02 RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS.
   (a)   All owners of property within the City, whose property abuts upon
sidewalks on City streets, shall keep such sidewalks in good repair and free
from defects, snow, ice, water and other obstruction or dangerous conditions.
The ground between sidewalk and street curb or gutter shall be kept graded so
that water will drain from sidewalks. If such sidewalks become defective,
dangerous or obstructed in any way, the Safety Service Director may proceed to
remove such defects, dangerous conditions or obstructions and grade the areas
between sidewalks and curbs so that water will drain from such walks.
   (b)   Any new building constructed on any parcel that is not subject to
Chapter
1109  of the Planning and Zoning Code shall construct a concrete sidewalk in
the public right-of-way and parallel to the street frontage unless otherwise
approved. Corner lots shall include the installation of sidewalks on both
frontages to include handicap accessible crossing ramps as required. The
Building Official shall not issue a final certificate of occupancy for the
newly constructed building without the sidewalk being installed.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.03  GENERAL CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
   All sidewalks constructed or repaired on City streets or alleys or on public
property shall be in accordance with design standards, plans and specifications
prepared by the City Engineer and building code standards as provided in part
thirteen, title one of the Amherst Codified Ordinances, under the direction and
inspection and to the satisfaction of the Building Official or his authorized
agent.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.04 RECONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR PROCEDURE.
   The City incorporates as part of the Amherst Codified Ordinances, as if
fully rewritten herein, Sections 729.01 through 729.10 of the Ohio Revised Code
as it pertains to City assessments for the construction or repair of sidewalks
within the City.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.05 EMERGENCY REPAIRS.
   Where no general resolution is passed by Council for any year, the Safety
Service Director, or their designee, may proceed as above for emergency
repairs.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.06 PERMIT FOR SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR.
   No person shall construct or repair sidewalks within the City right-of-way
without having obtained a permit therefor. The sidewalk construction permit
shall be obtained from the Building Department at no cost to the property
owner. The purpose of the permit is to insure the construction or repair is
completed in accordance with City design standards, plans, specifications and
building code standards.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)
   903.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, or any effective rule
or regulation promulgated hereunder, or fails to comply therewith or with any
written notice or written order issued hereunder, or whoever refuses to permit
lawful entry by the City or their representatives, and whoever interferes with,
obstructs or hinders such attempt to make a lawful inspection or repair, shall
be fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each offense. Each
day such violation of this chapter is committed, continued or permitted shall
constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   The imposition of any penalty shall not preclude the Law Director from
instituting an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of proper
jurisdiction to prevent an unlawful repair or maintenance; or to correct or
abate a violation, or to prevent the compliance with the provisions of this
chapter, or other applicable laws, ordinances, rules or regulations, or the
orders or determinations of the Building Official or the Board.
(Ord. 17-28. Passed 7-10-17.)

CHAPTER 909
Utilities in Public Right-of-Way
909.01   Permit required.
909.02   Review of application.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Use of municipal public way - Ohio R.C. Chapter 4939
      Use of Public Ways for Small Cell Wireless Facilities and Wireless
Support
         Structures - see S. & P.S. Chapter
925
   909.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Any person, firm, corporation or other who desires to install any utility or
other infrastructure within any public right-of-way located within the City of
Amherst shall first apply for, and obtain from the Mayor, a permit therefor. As
part of such application, the applicant shall provide the following:
   (a)   Detailed design drawings of the proposed improvements, prepared by a
professional engineer and/or registered surveyor showing existing topography
and utilities, horizontal and vertical locations of the proposed facility,
details of areas of potential conflict with existing utilities; and,
   (b)   A description of the method of public concrete/asphalt flatwork
crossings if any, (i.e., open-ended excavation, directional drilling,
horizontal bore, etc.); and,
   (c)   Details for concrete/asphalt replacement and repair together with an
estimate for the replacement/repair limits; and,
   (d)   Plans for traffic maintenance during construction of the facility;
and,
   (e)   A signed Right-of-Way Use Agreement, as provided by the City of
Amherst, which includes, but is not limited to, acknowledgement that the City
of Amherst shall not be responsible for any damage or repair/restoration of the
applicant's facilities located within the right-of-way; agreement to relocate
the facility, at the applicant's expense, when accommodation for future
roadways and/or other infrastructure improvement is deemed by the City to be
necessary; acknowledgment of applicant's responsibility for the repair/
replacement of other utilities encountered and/or damaged during the course of
the project; agreement to hold the City harmless for any damage, or damage
claims of others, arising or resulting from the installation of the facility;
agreement for the proper repair/restoration, at no cost to the City, of areas
associated with the installation of the facility, including but not limited to
tree lawn grading/topsoil replacement, seeding and straw placement, sidewalks,
driveway and street pavement/curb and gutter repair/replacement; and, proof of
liability insurance, naming the City of Amherst as an additional insured, in
the amounts listed within the Right-of-Way Use Agreement, during and for all
work to be completed in connection with the project.
      (Ord. 20-28. Passed 10-26-20.)
   909.02 REVIEW OF APPLICATION.
   Upon the application of any person, firm, corporation or other who desires
to install any utility or infrastructure with any public right-of-way within
the City of Amherst, the Mayor shall review said application and shall forward
all application materials to the applicable municipal departments and Law
Director for their review and approval. The City may require and the applicant
shall agree to relocate its facility as determined by the City's engineer.
(Ord. 20-28. Passed 10-26-20.)

1115.04
      Testing sanitary sewers in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1115.06
   911.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Sanitary sewage" means the waste from water closets, urinals,
lavatories, sinks, bathtubs, showers, household laundries, cellar floor drains,
bars, soda fountains, cuspidors, refrigerator drips and drinking fountains and
any other water-borne waste not constituting an industrial waste.
   (b)    "Acceptable industrial wastes" means any liquid organic waste
materials not containing toxic or explosive elements or other substances
injurious to sewers or sewage treatment processes which result from any
commercial, manufacturing or industrial operation or process.
   (c)    "Nonacceptable industrial wastes" means any liquid wastes in which
are incorporated minerals, oil, acid or toxic metallic or chemical substances,
resulting from any commercial, manufacturing or industrial operation or
process.
      (Ord. B-513. Passed 6-19-56.)
   (d)    "Street" means all streets, lanes, alleys or other public grounds,
the same as though named in each case.
      (Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.02 AUTHORITY AND CONTROL.
   The Superintendent of Sewers shall have full charge of the maintenance and
repair of the City sewerage system and sewage disposal plant as provided by
ordinance and under the general direction of Council and the Director of Public
Service. He or his assistants shall inspect each and every new connection and
shall make a permanent record of the location of such connections. All sanitary
sewers and drains of every kind within the line of any street, lane, alley or
other public grounds or right of way shall be under the control of the
Superintendent of Sewers.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.03 ACCESS TO HOUSE DRAINAGE SYSTEM.
   All sanitary sewers, drains, urinals, sewer gas and waste traps and pipes,
vaults, cesspools and everything pertaining to house drainage beyond the lines
of any street, lane, alley or other public grounds shall be accessible to the
Superintendent of Sewers, his assistants and the County Health Officer and
shall, except where otherwise provided, be under the care and control of the
County Health Officer.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.04 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall be authorized or permitted to do the work of tapping or
making connections with any of the public sewers or drains or their lateral
drains until he has first made application for a permit to the Superintendent
of Sewers.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.05 APPLICATION; SEPARATE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED; LOCATION DESIGNATED.
   Applications for permits shall be made by the owner to the Superintendent of
Sewers who shall issue a permit to the owner before the work is commenced. In
no case shall work be done unless such permit is on the ground and in
possession of the person doing the work. Each permit shall designate the street
and number of the lot, shall indicate the side of the street and shall include
such definite description of the premises as to clearly define its location on
the map. Each permit shall also designate the location and depth of the
connection at the main sewer and at the curb or property line of the street.
   Each dwelling must have a distinct and separate connection with the sewer.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.06 CONNECTION PERMIT RECORDS AND FEES.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
911.06 was repealed by Ordinance 73-4, passed January 22, 1973. See Section
913.07 for general tap-in charges.)
   911.07 ACCESS TO FIXTURES.
   The Superintendent of Sewers shall at any reasonable time have access to
plumbing fixtures connected with the sewerage system.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.08 RECORD OF SEWER LOCATION AND DEPTH.
   The City will keep a permanent record of the location of sanitary sewers
junctures or connecting branches, depth of sewers, etc., which information may
be obtained from the City upon the application for a permit.
   All reasonable care will be taken to insure correctness of such information,
but the City shall not be liable for errors arising therefrom.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.09 METHOD AND DEPTH OF CONNECTIONS TO CITY SEWERS.
   All connections with main or branch sewers shall be made at regular
connecting branches built in the sewers, except by special permit from the
Superintendent of Sewers. Whenever it is necessary to make a connection with
any main or lateral sewer where no connection has been placed, the connection
will be made by the owner, but no cutting or breaking into the sewer shall be
done unless the Superintendent of Sewers or one of his assistants is present at
the work site and gives his approval of the method employed.
   All house connections shall be made straight, or in as direct line as
possible to the connecting branches in the sewer into which the premises are
drained and such connections shall be at least four feet below the surface of
the ground.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.10 SEWER PIPE SIZE, QUALITY, GRADE AND JOINTS.
   All sewer pipes shall be of uniform size with the connecting tap. They
shall, except those which enter buildings, be of the best quality of PVC
plastic pipe, acceptable to the Superintendent of Sewers. All pipes shall be
laid to proper grade of not less than four percent (4%) grade where
practicable, by the use of the spirit level. The joints shall be well sealed,
so that the same will be watertight. Two forty-five degree angles shall be used
in place of a ninety degree angle in deviation from a straight line in the
length of one joint of pipe.
(Ord. 86-17. Passed 3-10-86.)
   911.11 HOUSE CONNECTION METHOD AND MATERIALS.
   The PVC plastic pipe shall be discontinued three feet outside of the walls
or foundation of the buildings and shall be continued with cast iron pipe or
plastic pipe of the same diameter. In either case, the cast iron pipe or
plastic pipe shall meet approved standards for plumbing installations as
provided in the Regional Dwelling House Code, copyright 1966, prepared by
Cuyahoga County Regional Planning Commission. The six by six by four pipe
cleanout just inside the wall shall be capped and no connection to the house
system shall be made until installation has been tested and approved. All iron
pipe used in the construction of drains or house connections shall be coded
inside and outside with cold tar applied hot or with other nonrusting material
acceptable to the Superintendent of Sewers. The joints of iron pipe shall be
with gaskets of oakam, thoroughly sealed in with hot lead at one pouring so as
to render them impermeable to gases, but wrought iron pipe with screw joints
may also be used. All plastic pipe, fittings and joints shall be as provided in
the Regional Dwelling House Code as aforesaid.
(Ord. 86-17. Passed 3-10-86.)
   911.111 SPECIFICATION FOR POLYVINYL CHLORIDE (PVC) PLASTIC PIPE FOR HOUSE
LEAD LATERAL SEWER PIPE.
   PVC plastic pipe shall meet the requirements of ASTM D3034, "Type PSM Poly
(Vinyl Chloride) (PVC) Sewer Pipe and Fittings", SDR-35. All pipe shall be made
of PVC plastic conforming to the requirements of ASTM D1784. All joints shall
be of the elastomeric gasket joint (integral bell) type and shall meet the
requirements of ASTM D3212. The bell shall be designed to retain the gasket to
prevent pull out during the making of the joint and the spigot end shall have a
clearly marked depth of entry ring. The pipe shall be installed in accordance
with the requirements of ASTM D2321 and shall have a minimum of six inches of
thoroughly computed granular bedding material under, around, and above the
pipe. Granular bedding material shall meet the requirement of Ohio Department
of Transportation (ODOT) Construction and Material Specifications Item 304 or
411.
(Ord. 86-17. Passed 3-10-86.)
   911.12 SOIL PIPE LOCATION AND QUALITY.
   When it is necessary, the soil pipe shall run on a cellar wall and be
fastened securely thereto. Where possible, the soil pipe shall be laid in a
trench beneath the cellar floor. The soil pipe shall be supplied with
accessible cleanouts just inside of the walls of the building. Waste pipes or
lateral drains from bathtubs, basins or other fixtures must be connected with
main soil pipe by means of proper connections.
   The nearly horizontal portion of iron soil pipe used underground shall in no
case be less than C.I.P.X., and if copper pipe is used aboveground, then the
C.I.P.X. shall come fourteen inches above the floor.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.13 PIPE INTERIOR AND CASING.
   All connecting sewer pipe branches or junctures, whether or not intended for
immediate use, shall stand a twenty pound test. Care shall be taken that the
interior of the pipes is free from obstructions and that the whole house
connections and sewer are left clean and in good condition. All pipes exposed
to frost shall be packed with mineral wool or other substance equally good and
shall be cased to the satisfaction of the Superintendent of Sewers.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.14 COST BORNE BY PROPERTY OWNER.
   All the costs and expense of making a connection to any sewer or drain for
private use shall be borne by the property owner.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.15 REPAIR OF LATERALS WITHIN ROAD PROPERTY.
   (a)   Definitions. For the purposes of this section:
      (1)   “Lateral” means the line materials connecting the wastewater
collection system of a structure on private property to the main line of the
Amherst sanitary sewer system.
      (2)   “Road property” means any property that is within a dedicated and
accepted street right-of-way and that is either under the improved roadway
surface or within twelve inches of the curb or improved roadway surface.
      (3)   “Damage” to a lateral means the collapse of a sewer tile or tiles
that obstructs the flow of effluent in the sewer line or a separation of tiles
that causes an obstruction in the flow of effluent in the sewer line.
      (4)   “Road property lateral repair work” means:
         A.   Excavation within road property;
         B.   Opening, closing and returning the roadway to its former state;
and
         C.   Repairing or replacing line materials that lie within the road
property.
      (5)   “Routine maintenance and cleaning” means removal of tree roots,
foreign objects, accumulated grease or other obstructions that do not fall
within the definition of damage as defined in this section.
   (b)   Determination of Damage. For the purposes of this section, the only
acceptable method of identifying damage to a lateral shall be the use of an in-
line video camera system or comparable technology approved by the
Superintendent of Utilities, with the results recorded on video tape or disk.
   (c)   Applicability. In cases where there is determined to be a damage to
that portion of a lateral that lies within road property the City may, at the
discretion of the Safety/Service Director, pay all or part of the costs of the
road property lateral repair work. Such assistance shall only be paid if:
      (1)   The property owner or resident has engaged a professional plumber
who, using an in-line video system, has examined the entire lateral and
certified that there is damage to the portion of the lateral leading into the
resident’s home that lies within road property, and such plumber has provided a
copy of a video tape or disk of the examination of the entire lateral to the
Superintendent of Utilities for review.
      (2)   The Superintendent of Utilities has examined the report of the
plumber and/or video tape or disk produced by the in-line camera and concurs
that there is damage requiring repairs in that part of the lateral that lies
within road property.
      (3)   The Superintendent of Utilities is not of the opinion that damage
to such lateral is due to failure of the property owner to maintain the lateral
or abusive or over-aggressive attempts by the property owner or someone engaged
by the property owner to remove blockages.
   (d)   Allocation of Repair Costs and Responsibilities. 
      (1)   If the Safety/Service Director approves the payment of all or part
of the costs of certain road property lateral repair work, then the property
owner may elect to have the repairs in road property performed by a licensed
private contractor and seek reimbursement from the City for the approved costs
or the property owner may request that the work be performed by City employees,
and, if the City’s cost of performing such work exceeds the amount the City has
agreed to pay, then the property owner shall reimburse the City for the excess.
The Superintendent of Utilities shall be responsible for determining if and
when City employees are available to work on projects covered under this
section. The use of private contractors must be approved in advance by the
Superintendent of Utilities and the City shall not reimburse the property owner
for an amount that exceeds what the City’s real and actual costs would be if
the road property lateral repair work had been performed by City employees as
determined by the Safety Service Director.
      (2)   If the video tape provided by the property owner also identifies
significant damage to that portion of the lateral that lies between the clean-
out and the edge of road property, the property owner shall, at such property
owner’s sole cost and expense, cause such damage to be repaired at the same
time as the repairs are being made on that portion of the lateral that lies
within road property.
      (3)   Work to repair any portion of a lateral outside road property may
not be performed by City employees.
      (4)   The property owner shall be responsible for repairing all damage to
any portion of a lateral that lies outside road property at such property
owner’s sole cost and expense.
   (e)   Routine Maintenance and Cleaning. The property owner shall be solely
responsible for routine maintenance and cleaning of the lateral from the clean-
out to the connection of the lateral to the sewer main.
   (f)   Liability for Property Damage. Nothing in this section shall be
interpreted in any way to make the City or any of its officials,
representatives or employees liable for damage to private property, the
structures thereon or the contents thereof resulting from a back-up of waste
water or materials attributable in whole or in part to damage to blockage of
any portion of a lateral.
   (g)   Development of Forms and Policies. The Safety/Service Director shall
develop standardized forms and written policies for use in documenting the
steps for all claims and requests submitted under this section.
   (h)   Effective Date. The section shall apply only in cases where the
initial damage to the lateral was first identified after the effective date of
this section.
(Ord. 02-79. Passed 8-26-02.)
   911.16 TRENCH CARE; SAFEGUARDS; OWNER'S LIABILITY.
   When the sides of the trench opened for sewer work will not stand vertical,
cribbing and braces shall be used to prevent caving.
   The property owner shall erect proper safeguards and maintain danger signals
and shall be liable for all damages to persons or property caused by his acts
or his negligence.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.17 SURFACE SETTLEMENT AND RESTORATION,
   Following sewer work trenching, the property owner shall also be held
responsible for any subsequent settlement of the surface of the street,
sidewalk, etc., and shall, upon notification, make the same as good as before
he began the work. If this is not done within ten days after receiving notice,
the City will do the work and assess the cost of the same against the property
owner.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.18 INSPECTION OF SEWERS; COVERING WORK.
   No drain or sewer connection shall be covered without due notice to the
Superintendent of Sewers or one of his assistants, and the same must be
uncovered for inspection at the direction of the Superintendent.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.19 EXPOSURE OF SOIL PIPE AND FIXTURES; WASTE PIPE CONNECTIONS.
   All vertical soil waste pipes and traps must, if practicable, be exposed to
view for ready inspection at all times and for convenience in repairing. Drips
or overflow pipes from all other fixtures or from tanks shall run to some place
in open sight and in no case shall such pipes be connected directly with a
drain, waste or soil pipe.
   Waste pipes from refrigerators or other receptacles in which provisions are
stored shall not be connected with a drain, soil or other waste pipe, unless
such waste pipes are provided with traps suitably ventilated. In every case
there shall be an open tray between the trap and the refrigerator.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.20 GREASE TRAPS AND STRAINERS; INSPECTIONS AND FEES.
   (a)   All private sewers connecting with packing houses or butcher shops,
laundries, hotels, eating houses, restaurants or other public cooking
establishments shall be provided with grease traps and strainers of such design
as approved by the State Board of Building Standards or which is otherwise
consistent with the provisions of the Ohio Plumbing Code.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   (b)   The City shall have the authority to inspect and enforce compliance
with the standards established in Section
911.20(a). There shall be a fifty dollar ($50.00) inspection fee for each
inspection until the private sewer connection is found to be in compliance with
the standards established in Section
911.20(a). The City may continue to inspect grease traps until compliance is
achieved. Unpaid inspection fees may be added to the utility bill for the user
of the private sewer connection described in the previous paragraph.
   (c)   If the City discovers a blockage in the private sewer connection, the
City may, at its option, clear the blockage and charge the user of the private
sewer connection described in the paragraph (a) of this section for the cost of
clearing the blockage. Such charges may also be added to the utility bill for
the user of the private sewer connection described in the previous paragraph or
liened against the real estate.
(Ord. 05-31. Passed 4-11-05.)
   911.21  STEAM BOILER CELLAR DRAINS.
   No steam exhaust or blow-off pipe from any steam boiler shall be allowed to
connect with any soil or waste pipe or directly with any house drain. It must
discharge into a tank or condenser, from which the waste, after being condensed
and suitably tapped, may enter the sewer.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.22 STORM WATER AND OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED.
   Elevator waste water, roof water, overflow from rain water cisterns, storm
water drainage, etc., shall not be connected with the sanitary sewer. The waste
water which shall enter the sanitary sewers shall comprise only sanitation
water and such water from factories, laundries, restaurants or other buildings
as the Superintendent of Sewers may consider admissible without detriment to
the sewer.
   No butcher's offal or garbage, dead animal, wood, stone, straw, rags,
machinist's waste or other articles of obstruction of any kind whatever of a
tougher or harder texture than toilet paper shall be placed, thrown or
deposited in any catch basin, sewer or drain of the City. Any person so
offending or causing any such obstruction to be placed so as to be carried into
such sewer or basin shall be subject to the penalty prescribed in Section
911.99. Any person breaking, injuring or removing any portion of any such catch
basin, manhole cover or any part of the sewer, sewage disposal plant or any
appurtenance thereto or obstructing in any manner the outlet of any sewer or
drain shall also be subject to the same penalty.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.23 CESSPOOLS AND VAULTS, USE AND DISCONTINUANCE.
   No cesspool or vault shall be connected with any private or public sewer. No
cesspool or vault will be allowed to exist in any basement or cellar.
   No sewer or kitchen drain from any building or premises shall discharge into
any cesspool, vault or other like receptacle, where such building or premises
abuts on a street provided with proper sewer accommodations with which the same
can be connected. If at any future time such premises are provided with such
sewerage accommodations within sixty days after notice, the future use of such
cesspools, vaults or other similar receptacles for the disposal of sewage shall
be discontinued and the proper connections made with the main or lateral sewer.
Such cesspools, vaults or other receptacles shall be cleaned out and filled
with earth or cinders under the direction of the Superintendent of Sewers.
   When a cesspool or vault must necessarily be used, it must be in accordance
with the regulations of the Lorain County Board of Health.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
   911.24 TREATMENT OF NONACCEPTABLE INDUSTRIAL WASTES
   The discharge of nonacceptable industrial wastes into the system, whether
directly or indirectly, is hereby prohibited. Where investigation reveals the
presence in the system of nonacceptable industrial wastes emanating from any
lot, land, building or premises, the owner, lessor, lessee or occupant of such
lot, land, building or premises shall be required to treat, neutralize or in
other ways prepare the noxious substance therein to the satisfaction of the
Director of Public Service in order to convert the same into acceptable
industrial wastes.
(Ord. B-513. Passed 6-19-56.)
   911.25 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Service shall make and enforce such rules and
regulations as he may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions of
this chapter, for the proper determination and collection of the rates and
charges provided in Chapter
913 and for the safe, efficient and economical management of the sewerage
system. Such rules and regulations, when not repugnant to existing ordinances
of the City or laws of the State, shall have the same force and effect as
ordinances of Council.
(Ord. B-513. Passed 6-19-56.)
   911.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). Each day the
violation exists, after notice has been given to the violator, may be classed
as a separate offense.
(Ord. B-423. Passed 4-3-51.)
